Course Description: The international market for Business Intelligence and Data warehouse is increasing rapidly and is currently estimated to be in hundreds of billion of US dollars. A number of Indian companies, even in NCR of Delhi, are already carrying out projects in the area. Yet, there is an acute shortage of skilled human resources in the subject and the course attempts to plug this gap. Students will be taken over the development life cycle of a data warehouse. The application environment in which a data warehouse is embedded shall be brought out so that the value of the new technology is clearly discernible.

Course Outcomes.CO1: Relate data warehousing to decision-making processes
Course Outcomes.CO2: Elicit required information for a decision
Course Outcomes.CO3: Design and implement the data warehouse architecture
Course Outcomes.CO4: Obtain Business Intelligence from the data warehouse

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Overview of Databases, Data Warehouse Definition, Decisions and their types, Decision making process
Influence and Augmented Influence diagrams Perspectives of DW: Basic Dimension Modeling
Decisional and DW Information Models Conversion to Dimension Model Computer Assisted Tools
Databases vs. Data Warehouses Star Schema Design
Fact Design, transaction, periodic snapshots, evolving snapshots, granularity Multiple and type specific stars
Evaluation of Decisional Tools of students
Dimension Design: Types, properties and design considerations
Dimension Design: Bridges, Attribute and Recursive Hierarchies, Transactions, snapshots
Operational Issues in Star Schema Design: NULLS, Special rows in Dimensions, snowflake schema issues
Data Warehouse Consolidation Agile DW development
Business Intelligence OLAP operations Mining Visualization

Resource Material.Textbook: Kimball R. and Ross M., The Data Warehouse Tool kit, Wiley Inmon , Imhoff, and Sousa, The Corporate Information Factory, Wiley Imhoff, Galemno, Geiger, Mastering Data Warehouse Design Wiley P. Ponniah, Data Warehouse Fundamentals, Wiley India Adamson C., Star Schema, Tata McGraw Hill Inmon, Building the Data warehouse, Wiley Prakash and Prakash, Data Warehouse Requirements Engineering, Springer Marakos G.M., Decision Support Systems, PHI
